rows.title: Introductions
rows.introduction: This first session offers a chance for members to introduce themselves to the group.
rows.message_1:
Hello and thanks for joining us in this chat. I hope you're all making progress in ParentText. Please DM me if you need help! 

Today we are introducing ourselves! Please share your name and your goal for the programme. As an example: 

My name is @fields.user_name and I want to learn more about how to help my child go to bed by 8 every night. 

Feel free to add your own to the chat using text or audio message.
rows.message_2:
Thanks so much for sharing! To make this a safe space for everyone, here are some ground rules: 
- What is said in the group stays in the group. You need to know that this group is private.
- Accept each other. Everyone is different and has different experiences.
- Share only what you feel comfortable sharing.
- Feel free to ask questions!
- Respect privacy of personal pictures and videos that are sent to the chat group. 

If you don't feel like you can agree to these rules, please send me a message and I can remove you from the group.

rows.title: One-on-One Time
rows.introduction:
This session allows parents to discuss the importance of one-on-one time with their child. Remember, the key building blocks for One-on-One time are Day, Play, and Stay:

**DAY** Try to do it every day
Spend 5 minutes (or more!) One-on-One time with your child each day.

**PLAY** Let them choose the activity
Tell your child that you would like to spend some time with them and that they can choose what to do or talk about. They might think this is weird at first but will come to enjoy this time with you!

**STAY** Focus on your child 
Switch off TV and put aside phones. Look at your child or teen. Nod or say “I see” to show you are really paying attention. Accept what they say without judging them.

The goal is for parents to spend at least 5 minutes of one-on-one time with their child each day.
rows.message_1:
Let’s move on to our first parenting tip! This week we are learning about spending 1-on-1 time with our children. 

Spending quality time with your children makes them feel secure and loved. Here are 3 things to try when you are spending One-on-One time with your children:

1️⃣ DAY. Try to spend One-on-One time with your children every day.

2️⃣ PLAY. Let them choose the activity.

3️⃣ STAY. Stay totally focused on your child. Show them you are paying attention by looking and responding to them.
rows.message_2: Why do you think spending One-on-One Time with your children could be helpful?
rows.message_3: Thanks for sharing so many wonderful responses! This week, remember to spend at least 5 minutes of one-on-one time with your child each day.
rows.faq_introduction: Give parents in your @global.share_medium group time to respond.
rows.response_1:
If your chat goes silent after the prompt, consider sharing some of these ideas or suggestions. 

One-on-One Time with Children Is Helpful Because It: 
- Improves the relationship between parents/caregivers and children.
- Children feel that they are valuable and loved.
- Shows children that what they are doing is important.
- Builds self-esteem of children and makes them feel important.
- Increases trust and improves communication between parents/caregivers and children.
- Helps children develop and explore the world.
- Gives parents/caregivers a chance to learn about children's interests and abilities.
rows.question_2: A parent cannot complete one-on-one time with their child this week.
rows.response_2:
That's okay! Parenting can be challenging and many obstacles can get in the way. Remember, your job isn't to solve their problems, but enable a conversation between parents to support one another. Here are some challenges and possible solutions you might share if other parents don't offer support: 

| Challenge                                                            | Possible solution                                                                              |
|----------------------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| I didn’t have enough time                                            | Find a chore to do together!                                                                   |
| My child did not want to spend time with me.                         | Try finding something fun to do.                                                               |
| All my child wanted to do is watch T.V. or play with a gadget        | Ask your child to show you something on the gadget.                                            |
| My child wanted to do things I felt uncomfortable about              | Explain why you feel uncomfortable and suggest an alternative.                                 |
| My child wanted to do activities that I could not do                 | Ask your child if you can watch!                                                               |
| My child chose a competitive activity. I won and then they got angry | Suggest other activities or do an activity where you can be on the same team.                  |
| My child had a tantrum at the end of One-on-One time                 | Be clear about how much time you have and warn your child when the time is coming to an end.   |
| All my children wanted One-on-One Time at the same time:             | Think of a time when other children are not around or ask another adult to help with children. |

rows.title: Sharing Emotions
rows.introduction:
The primary objectives for this week are parents learning and practicing how to talk about their own and their children’s feelings. 

The key building blocks for Talking about Emotions are Breathe, Share, Listen, Show, and Seek:

BREATHE. Slowly. Pause. 
Before you say anything, slowly breathe in and out. It will calm you and give you a chance to think.

SHARE how you feel
This is hard. Many of us were told not to cry or show our feelings to our children. But take a deep breath and calmly tell them how you feel. They will understand better, and also learn from you how to deal with stress. 

LISTEN to your child.
Allow your child to share their emotions. You can also reflect back what you them say to you. Accept that the feeling is okay, even if it is negative.

SHOW them you care
This is also hard! Stress makes us focus on ourselves. But our children and teens need our support. Ask them how they feel. Listen to them and comfort them. Try a hug or say, ‘I understand.’ It can change everything.

SEEK the positive
Can you and your child think about ideas that might help? Can you do something positive together to take your mind off the stress?
rows.message_1:
Today’s parent tip is about helping your children to manage their feelings. Here are 5 tips about how to talk about emotions with your children:

BREATHE to calm yourself before you start.
SHARE how you feel. 
LISTEN to your child or teen. 
SHOW them you care. 
SEEK the positive.
rows.message_2: Why do you think helping your child share their emotions could be helpful for them?
rows.message_3: Thanks for sharing your ideas! This week, practice talking to your children about their emotions during One-on-One Time and at other times during the week. Try to become more aware of your own emotions as you go about your day, too!
rows.faq_title: Key Issues to Be Aware Of
rows.question_1: Talking about emotions can be new
rows.response_1: It is completely normal for parents to have difficulty talking about and expressing emotions and feelings. Parents may be trying to recognise their own emotions and communicate about them for the first time here. Talking about feelings also has the benefit of bringing awareness to positive emotions such as happiness or calmness!
rows.response_2: Many people are taught not to cry when they are sad. This might be especially true for boys and men. It’s important to understand that boys and men have the same feelings as girls and women, and that sharing emotions does not need to reduce their sense of masculinity. Sharing emotions is a sign of courage and strength.
rows.response_3: Negative emotions are just as normal as positive emotions! Some parents might feel disrespected when their children display negative emotions. This does not mean that parents are losing control or authority over their child. Parents should encourage children to be aware of their emotions by helping them to name emotions, and to talk about how they are experiencing their emotions as this will help them to regulate their emotions.
